Contour methods for long-range Ising models: weakening nearest-neighbor interactions and adding decaying fields.
Rodrigo Bissacot1, Eric O. Endo1,2, Aernout C. D. van Enter2, Bruno Kimura3 and Wioletta M. Ruszel3 1Institute of Mathematics and Statistics (IME-USP), University of SÃ£o Paulo, Brazil 2Johann Bernoulli Institute, University of Groningen, the Netherlands 3Delft Institute for Applied Mathematics, Technical University Delft, the Netherlands emails: rodrigo.bissacot@gmail.com; eric@ime.usp.br; avanenter@gmail.com; bruno.hfkimura@gmail.com; w.m.ruszel@tudelft.nl


Abstract. We consider ferromagnetic long-range Ising models which display phase transitions. They are one-dimensional Ising ferromagnets, in which the interaction is given by Jx,y=Jâ€‹(|xâˆ’y|)â‰¡1|xâˆ’y|2âˆ’Î±subscriptğ½ğ‘¥ğ‘¦ğ½ğ‘¥ğ‘¦1superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦2ğ›¼J_{x,y}=J(|x-y|)\equiv\frac{1}{|x-y|^{2-\alpha}} with Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1), in particular, Jâ€‹(1)=1ğ½11J(1)=1. For this class of models one way in which one can prove the phase transition is via a kind of Peierls contour argument, using the adaptation of the FrÃ¶hlich-Spencer contours for Î±â‰ 0ğ›¼0\alpha\neq 0, proposed by Cassandro, Ferrari, Merola and Presutti. As proved by FrÃ¶hlich and Spencer for Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 and conjectured by Cassandro et al for the region they could treat, Î±âˆˆ(0,Î±+)ğ›¼0subscriptğ›¼\alpha\in(0,\alpha_{+}) for Î±+=logâ¡(3)/logâ¡(2)âˆ’1subscriptğ›¼321\alpha_{+}=\log(3)/\log(2)-1, although in the literature dealing with contour methods for these models it is generally assumed that Jâ€‹(1)â‰«1much-greater-thanğ½11J(1)\gg 1, we will show that this condition can be removed in the contour analysis. In addition, combining our theorem with a recent result of Littin and Picco we prove the persistence of the contour proof of the phase transition for any Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1). Moreover, we show that when we add a magnetic field decaying to zero, given by hx=hâˆ—â‹…(1+|x|)âˆ’Î³subscriptâ„ğ‘¥â‹…subscriptâ„superscript1ğ‘¥ğ›¾h_{x}=h_{*}\cdot(1+|x|)^{-\gamma} and Î³>maxâ¡{1âˆ’Î±,1âˆ’Î±âˆ—}ğ›¾1ğ›¼1superscriptğ›¼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha^{*}\} where Î±âˆ—â‰ˆ0.2714superscriptğ›¼0.2714\alpha^{*}\approx 0.2714, the transition still persists.

1. Introduction

The rigorous study of phase transitions for one-dimensional Ising models with long-range slowly decaying interactions (Dyson models) is a classical subject in one-dimensional statistical mechanics. One of the earliest highlights, almost 50 years ago, was Dysonâ€™s proof of a phase transition [16, 17, 18], proving a conjecture due to Kac and Thompson [24]. Long-range Ising models with slow polynomial decay, as well as the somewhat related hierarchical models, have been called â€œDyson modelsâ€ in the literature. We will mostly call our polynomially decaying models â€œlong-range Ising modelsâ€ but sometimes refer to them as â€œDyson modelsâ€.

The formal Hamiltonian of these models is given by:

(1.1) Hâ€‹(Ïƒ)=âˆ’âˆ‘xâ‰ yJx,yâ€‹Ïƒxâ€‹Ïƒyâˆ’âˆ‘xhxâ€‹Ïƒxğ»ğœsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğ½ğ‘¥ğ‘¦subscriptğœğ‘¥subscriptğœğ‘¦subscriptğ‘¥subscriptâ„ğ‘¥subscriptğœğ‘¥H(\sigma)=-\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}x\neq y\end{subarray}}J_{x,y}\sigma_{x}\sigma_{y}-\sum_{x}h_{x}\sigma_{x}

Here the sites x,yğ‘¥ğ‘¦x,y live in â„¤â„¤\mathbb{Z}, the Ïƒxsubscriptğœğ‘¥\sigma_{x} are Ising spins. More precise definitions are given in the next section. We first mention what is known for the zero-field case, i.e. when hx=0subscriptâ„ğ‘¥0h_{x}=0 for all xğ‘¥x.

We consider ferromagnetic interactions Jx,yâ‰¥0subscriptğ½ğ‘¥ğ‘¦0J_{x,y}\geq 0 given by Jx,y=|xâˆ’y|âˆ’2+Î±subscriptğ½ğ‘¥ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘¥ğ‘¦2ğ›¼J_{x,y}=|x-y|^{-2+\alpha} with Î±<1ğ›¼1\alpha<1. It is well known that for Î±<0ğ›¼0\alpha<0 there is no phase transition, and Dyson showed in [16] via comparison with a hierarchical model, that, for Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1), we have a phase transition at low temperature.

Afterwards different proofs were invented to show the transition. One of them used Reflection Positivity [19]. The method of infrared bounds offers an alternative to obtaining bounds on contour probabilities. In fact, the authors of [19] remark that they can cover a general class of long-range one-dimensional pair interactions, including the ones treated in [16].

Shortly after, FrÃ¶hlich and Spencer [20] showed the existence of a phase transition for Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0. The proof of these authors was done by a contour argument; they invented a notion of one-dimensional contours on â„¤â„¤\mathbb{Z} in order to prove the phase transition. Their strategy more or less followed the classical Peierls contour argument used for the standard nearest-neighbor Ising model, but with a substantially more sophisticated definition of contours. Phase transitions for larger Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1) can then be deduced by Griffiths inequalities for low enough temperature.

Yet another way to derive the transition was a comparison with independent long-range percolation via Fortuin inequalities and Griffiths inequalities for the Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 case, as discussed in [1]. In that paper it was also shown that the transition for Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 is a hybrid one, in the sense that the magnetisation is discontinuous and at the same time the energy is continuous as a function of temperature (Thouless effect). Moreover, for Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 it is known that there is a temperature interval below the transition temperature where the system is critical, in the sense that the covariance is nonsummable, and at the same time the system is magnetized.

Cassandro et al. in [10] rigorously formalized the contour argument of [20] in the parameter regime 0â‰¤Î±<Î±+0ğ›¼subscriptğ›¼0\leq\alpha<\alpha_{+}, where Î±+:=logâ¡3/logâ¡2âˆ’1â‰ˆ0.5849assignsubscriptğ›¼3210.5849\alpha_{+}:=\log 3/\log 2-1\approx 0.5849. The construction allows a more precise description of various properties of the model. It has been used in various follow-up papers [8, 11, 12, 13, 14, 27, 29]. We should emphasize that, although the use of contour arguments may look somewhat unwieldy in comparison with other approaches, it is much more robust. Indeed it has been used to analyze Dyson models in random [13, 14] and periodic fields [25], for interface behaviour and phase separation [11, 12], for entropic repulsion [8], and here for the model in decaying magnetic fields, all problems where alternative methods appear to break down.

See also [23] for another, somewhat related approach.

However, the adaptation proposed by Cassandro et al. in [10] needed the following technical assumptions: (A1): Î±âˆˆ[0,Î±+)ğ›¼0superscriptğ›¼\alpha\in[0,\alpha^{+}) and (A2): Jâ€‹(1)â‰«1much-greater-thanğ½11J(1)\gg 1.

Even the case of Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0, previously obtained by FrÃ¶hlich and Spencer, needs Jâ€‹(1)â‰«1much-greater-thanğ½11J(1)\gg 1 in the adaptation proposed by them. The intuition behind the condition is more or less clear; it makes the model closer to a nearest-neighbor interaction model where, in principle, contour arguments might work more easily. Despite the condition being rather artificial and proof-generated, the constraint asking for Jâ€‹(1)â‰«1much-greater-thanğ½11J(1)\gg 1 is present in many later papers about Dyson models and the proof presented in [10] depends strongly on this hypothesis.

As regards the restriction on Î±ğ›¼\alpha, Littin in his thesis [27], and then Littin and Picco [29], showed that, using quasi-additive properties of the Hamiltonian of the corresponding contour model and applying the results from [10], one can modify the contour argument so that it implies the phase transition for all Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1). Due to the fact that the authors in [29] use energetic lower bounds from [10] which assume large nearest-neighbour interaction Jâ€‹(1)ğ½1J(1), they still use assumption (A2) in their arguments.

Our motivation for the present work is two-fold: first we want to present an argument to remove assumption (A2) for the zero-field case and secondly we want to show persistence of a phase transition for one-dimensional long-range models in the presence of external fields decaying to zero at infinity with a power Î³ğ›¾\gamma, in particular, for fields given by hx=hâˆ—â€‹(1+|x|)âˆ’Î³subscriptâ„ğ‘¥subscriptâ„superscript1ğ‘¥ğ›¾h_{x}=h_{*}(1+|x|)^{-\gamma} and 1âˆ’Î±<Î³1ğ›¼ğ›¾1-\alpha<\gamma. More precisely, our results combined with existing results imply that there is a trade-off between the restricting the parameter range of Î³ğ›¾\gamma to Î³>maxâ¡{1âˆ’Î±,1âˆ’Î±âˆ—}ğ›¾1ğ›¼1superscriptğ›¼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha^{*}\} and general Jâ€‹(1)ğ½1J(1) and assuming Jâ€‹(1)â‰«1much-greater-thanğ½11J(1)\gg 1 and choosing Î³>maxâ¡{1âˆ’Î±,1âˆ’Î±+}ğ›¾1ğ›¼1subscriptğ›¼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha_{+}\} where Î±+>Î±âˆ—subscriptğ›¼superscriptğ›¼\alpha_{+}>\alpha^{*} will be specified later. Note that our results apply to the latter case as well.

Before describing the rest of the paper, we will discuss briefly the context of these results with respect to the hypotheses and technicalities of the proof. Let us mention that a short announcement of some of our results, but without rigorous proofs, is contained in [7].

Considering the first result in the zero-field case, although proofs for the existence of a phase transition were known, our estimates allow firstly to drop the (A2) assumption, and then, by using monotonicity of the Hamiltonian with respect to Î±ğ›¼\alpha, we are also able to remove the first assumption (A1).

As regarding the decaying-field case we know that phase transitions for non-zero uniform fields are forbidden due to the Lee-Yang circle theorem [26].

The heuristics behind the inequality 1âˆ’Î±<Î³1ğ›¼ğ›¾1-\alpha<\gamma can be obtained as follows. We observe that the contribution of the interaction of a finite interval Î›Î›\Lambda with its complement is of order Oâ€‹(|Î›|Î±)ğ‘‚superscriptÎ›ğ›¼O(|\Lambda|^{\alpha}), whereas the contribution from the external field is of order Oâ€‹(|Î›|1âˆ’Î³)ğ‘‚superscriptÎ›1ğ›¾O(|\Lambda|^{1-\gamma}).

We now compare the exponents. If the interaction energy dominates the field energy for large Î›Î›\Lambda, a contour argument has a chance of working. This intuition is also what is underlying Imry-Ma arguments for analyzing the stability of phase transitions in the presence of random fields. It has been confirmed for decaying fields in higher-dimensional nearest-neighbour models, see below.

It can also be applied to a decaying field the strength of which decays with power Î³ğ›¾\gamma but which has random signs. In this case the field energy behaves like Oâ€‹(|Î›|12âˆ’Î³)ğ‘‚superscriptÎ›12ğ›¾O(|\Lambda|^{\frac{1}{2}-\gamma}). This case has also been considered before by J. Littin (private communication) [28]. We note that the case Î³=0ğ›¾0\gamma=0 reduces to the known Imry-Ma analysis as presented in [13, 14].

Note that the analogous question of the persistence of phase transitions in decaying fields already was studied before in some short-range models, see [5, 4, 6, 15].

The paper is organized as follows. In the section 2 we introduce the definition of the model and some notation. The following section 3 presents the main results. Section 4 introduces the construction of the contours and section 5 contains the proofs of the main theorems including the Peierls argument. Finally section 6 concludes with a summary and discussion about open questions.

3. Main Results

In this section we present our main results. The first result concerns the phase transition for the Dyson model for any Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1) and removing the Jâ€‹(1)â‰«1much-greater-thanğ½11J(1)\gg 1 assumption and the second result concerns the persistence of the phase transition under decaying external fields.

    Î±âˆˆ[0,Î±âˆ—)ğ›¼0superscriptğ›¼\alpha\in[0,\alpha^{*}), Jâ€‹(1)=1ğ½11J(1)=1, Î³=1âˆ’Î±ğ›¾1ğ›¼\gamma=1-\alpha and hâˆ—subscriptâ„h_{*} small enough.

Then there exists Î²c>0subscriptğ›½ğ‘0\beta_{c}>0 such that for all Î²>Î²cğ›½subscriptğ›½ğ‘\beta>\beta_{c} we have that |ğ’¢â€‹(hÂ¯,Î²)|>1ğ’¢Â¯â„ğ›½1|\mathcal{G}(\overline{h},\beta)|>1.

Remark: In the case of Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0, although it is the most complicated in general (the proof of the phase transition took more time [20], there is a mixed first-order second-order transition -the Thouless effect, as proven in [1], see also [31]- and there exists an intermediate phase, magnetised but with nonsummable covariance [22] in some temperature interval below the transition temperature), for our problem the situation becomes actually somewhat simpler. Indeed, in that case the condition Î³>1ğ›¾1\gamma>1 implies that the field energy is uniformly bounded, and thus the phase transition persists, whenever it occurs, due to the arguments of [5]. This applies at all temperatures where there is a phase transition, including the intermediate phase, and is not dependent on the applicability of contour arguments. However, for the critical value Î³=1ğ›¾1\gamma=1 and the field strength weak enough, our proof does apply only at very low temperatures.

4. Triangles and contours

The proof will consist of a Peierls type argument in one dimension. We start by defining the notion of triangles which was first described in [20] for Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0 and adapted for 0â‰¤Î±<10ğ›¼10\leq\alpha<1 in [10].

Given a configuration Ïƒâˆˆ{âˆ’1,+1}Î›ğœsuperscript11Î›\sigma\in\{-1,+1\}^{\Lambda}, let us define configurations of triangles. A spin -flip point is a site iğ‘–i in Î›âˆ—superscriptÎ›\Lambda^{*} such that Ïƒiâˆ’12â‰ Ïƒi+12subscriptğœğ‘–12subscriptğœğ‘–12\sigma_{i-\frac{1}{2}}\neq\sigma_{i+\frac{1}{2}}. For each spin-flip point iğ‘–i, let us consider the interval [iâˆ’1100,i+1100]âŠ‚â„ğ‘–1100ğ‘–1100â„\left[i-\frac{1}{100},i+\frac{1}{100}\right]\subset\mathbb{R} and choose a real number risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} in this interval such that, for every four distinct rilsubscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘™r_{i_{l}} with l=1,â€¦,4ğ‘™1â€¦4l=1,\ldots,4, we have |ri1âˆ’ri2|â‰ |ri3âˆ’ri4|subscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–1subscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–2subscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–3subscriptğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘–4|r_{i_{1}}-r_{i_{2}}|\neq|r_{i_{3}}-r_{i_{4}}|. The risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} are the bases of the triangles, and the last condition on risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} is to avoid ambiguity in the construction of the triangles below.

For each spin-flip point iğ‘–i, we start growing a â€œâˆ¨\lor-lineâ€ at risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} where this âˆ¨\lor-line is embedded in â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2} with angles Ï€/4ğœ‹4\pi/4 and 3â€‹Ï€/43ğœ‹43\pi/4. The process can also be seen in the following way: for each risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}, we draw a straight vertical line passing through it. Take the smallest distance between these lines, let us call the corresponding risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} and rjsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘—r_{j} the spin-flip points of these lines, and draw a isosceles triangle with base angle Ï€/4ğœ‹4\pi/4. Then, remove the lines associated to risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} and rjsubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘—r_{j}, and continue the process.

Note that, for any finite interval Î›Î›\Lambda with homogeneous boundary condition, the number of spin flips is even, and so every risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} is a vertex of some triangle. Entropy of Contours

For any kind of Peierls argument [30] where a notion of a contour is used to obtain the phase transition for a model, the entropy of the contours (that is the -logarithm of- the number of contours of a given size) should be controlled. Recently, generating functions were used on this combinatorial problem of counting contours associated to short-range models on regular trees [2] and on â„¤d,dâ‰¥2superscriptâ„¤ğ‘‘ğ‘‘2\mathbb{Z}^{d},d\geq 2, see [3]. For trees the method allows us to find the exact number of contours of a fixed size and for â„¤dsuperscriptâ„¤ğ‘‘\mathbb{Z}^{d} these are the best estimates until now.

The entropy of contours introduced in [10] was inspired by [20] and it satisfies the following estimates:

For any real b>0ğ‘0b>0 large enough and integer mâ‰¥1ğ‘š1m\geq 1, we have, for Î±âˆˆ(0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in(0,1),

(4.14) âˆ‘|Î“|=m0âˆˆÎ“eâˆ’bâ€‹âˆ‘TâˆˆÎ“|T|Î±â‰¤2â€‹mâ€‹eâˆ’bâ€‹mÎ±.subscriptÎ“ğ‘š0Î“superscriptğ‘’ğ‘subscriptğ‘‡Î“superscriptğ‘‡ğ›¼2ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘superscriptğ‘šğ›¼\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}|\Gamma|=m\\ 0\in\Gamma\end{subarray}}e^{-b\sum_{T\in\Gamma}|T|^{\alpha}}\leq 2me^{-bm^{\alpha}}.

In the case Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0,

(4.15) âˆ‘|Î“|=m0âˆˆÎ“eâˆ’bâ€‹âˆ‘TâˆˆÎ“(logâ¡(|T|)+4)â‰¤2â€‹mâ€‹eâˆ’bâ€‹(logâ¡m+4).subscriptÎ“ğ‘š0Î“superscriptğ‘’ğ‘subscriptğ‘‡Î“ğ‘‡42ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘ğ‘š4\sum_{\begin{subarray}{c}|\Gamma|=m\\ 0\in\Gamma\end{subarray}}e^{-b\sum_{T\in\Gamma}(\log(|T|)+4)}\leq 2me^{-b(\log m+4)}.

The proof is done by induction on mğ‘šm and using a graphical representation of contours by trees. This representation requires a process, called the square process, to create the structure of a tree from any contour. The existence of such an algorithm can be found in [10].

Quasi-additive properties of the Hamiltonian

In order to control the energy for the proof of phase transition via contours, Cassandro et al. in [10] showed that there exist CÎ±>0subscriptğ¶ğ›¼0C_{\alpha}>0 for Î±âˆˆ(0,Î±+)ğ›¼0subscriptğ›¼\alpha\in(0,\alpha_{+}) such that

(4.16) HÎ±+â€‹(Î“0|Î“Â¯\{Î“0})â‰¥CÎ±2â€‹âˆ‘TâˆˆÎ“0|T|Î±,superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ›¼conditionalsubscriptÎ“0\Â¯Î“subscriptÎ“0subscriptğ¶ğ›¼2subscriptğ‘‡subscriptÎ“0superscriptğ‘‡ğ›¼H_{\alpha}^{+}(\Gamma_{0}|\underline{\Gamma}\backslash\{\Gamma_{0}\})\geq\frac{C_{\alpha}}{2}\sum_{T\in\Gamma_{0}}|T|^{\alpha},

and

(4.17) HÎ±+â€‹(Î“0|Î“Â¯\{Î“0})â‰¥C02â€‹âˆ‘TâˆˆÎ“0logâ¡(|T|+4),superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ›¼conditionalsubscriptÎ“0\Â¯Î“subscriptÎ“0subscriptğ¶02subscriptğ‘‡subscriptÎ“0ğ‘‡4H_{\alpha}^{+}(\Gamma_{0}|\underline{\Gamma}\backslash\{\Gamma_{0}\})\geq\frac{C_{0}}{2}\sum_{T\in\Gamma_{0}}\log(|T|+4),

for Î±=0ğ›¼0\alpha=0. The constant CÎ±=3âˆ’21+Î±Î±â€‹(1âˆ’Î±)subscriptğ¶ğ›¼3superscript21ğ›¼ğ›¼1ğ›¼C_{\alpha}=\frac{3-2^{1+\alpha}}{\alpha(1-\alpha)} converges to zero when Î±â†’Î±+â†’ğ›¼subscriptğ›¼\alpha\to\alpha_{+}. Those bounds only work when the energy of the nearest neighbors Jâ€‹(1)ğ½1J(1) is large enough. Littin and Picco [29] showed that there is no possibility to extend those bounds in terms of triangles to any Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1), constructing a sequence of contours (Î“n)nâ‰¥1subscriptsubscriptÎ“ğ‘›ğ‘›1(\Gamma_{n})_{n\geq 1} such that

for 0â‰¤Î±<Î±+0ğ›¼subscriptğ›¼0\leq\alpha<\alpha_{+}.

Their construction explains, in some sense, the value of the constant Î±+=logâ¡3/logâ¡2âˆ’1subscriptğ›¼321\alpha_{+}=\log 3/\log 2-1 which could be considered kind of magical, since the Hausdorff dimension of the Cantor set is exactly logâ¡2/logâ¡323\log 2/\log 3. In fact, a discrete Cantor set appears in the construction. However, [29] showed the quasi-additive property of the Hamiltonian for any Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1), in other words, the following inequality is satisfied,

(4.19) HÎ±+â€‹(Î“0|Î“Â¯\{Î“0})â‰¥Kcâ€‹(Î±)â€‹HÎ±+â€‹[Î“0],superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ›¼conditionalsubscriptÎ“0\Â¯Î“subscriptÎ“0subscriptğ¾ğ‘ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ»ğ›¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ“0H_{\alpha}^{+}(\Gamma_{0}|\underline{\Gamma}\backslash\{\Gamma_{0}\})\geq K_{c}(\alpha)H_{\alpha}^{+}[\Gamma_{0}],

where Kcâ€‹(Î±)=1âˆ’Î±cÎ±âˆ’1âˆ’Ï€26â€‹csubscriptğ¾ğ‘ğ›¼1ğ›¼superscriptğ‘ğ›¼1superscriptğœ‹26ğ‘K_{c}(\alpha)=1-\frac{\alpha}{c^{\alpha-1}}-\frac{\pi^{2}}{6c} satisfies 0<Kcâ€‹(Î±)â‰¤120subscriptğ¾ğ‘ğ›¼120<K_{c}(\alpha)\leq\frac{1}{2} where cğ‘c is large enough. This property allows the authors to prove the phase transition for any Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1) as a corollary from the case when Î±âˆˆ[0,Î±+)ğ›¼0subscriptğ›¼\alpha\in[0,\alpha_{+}). As [29] mentioned, FrÃ¶hlich and Spencer [20] already noticed that the Hamiltonian satisfies the quasi-additivity.

5.2. Proof of Theorem 2

We can consider this modified field without loss of generality because any local perturbation does not change the fact that the model undergoes a phase transition. This is the reason that we do not need to consider Î³>1ğ›¾1\gamma>1 since in that case the external field is summable, see [21] for more details.

6. Concluding remarks

In this paper we provided further steps on the way to a better understanding of Dyson models. We were able to remove the artificial hypothesis of Jâ€‹(1)â‰«1much-greater-thanğ½11J(1)\gg 1, which is required in most of the literature about contour methods in these models, for the whole range of the exponent of the interaction Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1) in the direct proof of the phase transition via contours. The result suggests that this hypothesis can also be removed in all the subsequent papers based on the contour argument from [10].

Our analysis also allows us to include the case of decaying fields of the type defined by hx=hâˆ—â‹…(1+|x|)âˆ’Î³subscriptâ„ğ‘¥â‹…subscriptâ„superscript1ğ‘¥ğ›¾h_{x}=h_{*}\cdot(1+|x|)^{-\gamma}, previously considered in short-range models in [4, 5, 15, 6]. We proved the phase transition for any Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1) when Î³>maxâ¡{1âˆ’Î±,1âˆ’Î±âˆ—}ğ›¾1ğ›¼1superscriptğ›¼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha^{*}\}, combining our estimates with a recent approach proposed in [29]. As mentioned in the introduction, if we allow for the nearest-neighbour term to be large we can obtain a larger parameter range for Î³ğ›¾\gamma, namely Î³>maxâ¡{1âˆ’Î±,1âˆ’Î±+}ğ›¾1ğ›¼1subscriptğ›¼\gamma>\max\{1-\alpha,1-\alpha_{+}\} where Î±âˆ—<Î±+superscriptğ›¼subscriptğ›¼\alpha^{*}<\alpha_{+}. The entropy bound of [10] can be applied to contour weights wâ€‹(Î“)ğ‘¤Î“w(\Gamma) involving the exponential of the â€œcontour normâ€ â€–Î“â€–Î±subscriptnormÎ“ğ›¼||\Gamma||_{\alpha}. The reason why we cannot obtain a phase transition for Î³>1âˆ’Î±ğ›¾1ğ›¼\gamma>1-\alpha for all Î±âˆˆ[0,1)ğ›¼01\alpha\in[0,1) is that when we add a field, we cannot lower-bound the contour energy by a constant times some appropriate Î±ğ›¼\alpha-contour norm for Î±â‰¥Î±âˆ—ğ›¼superscriptğ›¼\alpha\geq\alpha^{*}. One would need another entropy bound in order to tackle this problem. This is one possibility for further research.

The critical case seems to be similar to the standard Ising model with decaying fields, see [4]. In fact, for any 0â‰¤Î±<10ğ›¼10\leq\alpha<1 we proved the phase transition when 1âˆ’Î±âˆ—<1âˆ’Î±=Î³1superscriptğ›¼1ğ›¼ğ›¾1-\alpha^{*}<1-\alpha=\gamma. For the case when hâˆ—subscriptâ„h_{*} is large and the model has a nearest-neighbour ferromagnetic interaction on â„¤dsuperscriptâ„¤ğ‘‘\mathbb{Z}^{d}, dâ‰¥2ğ‘‘2d\geq 2, this question is still an open problem and there is some hope to see phase uniqueness for large values of hâˆ—subscriptâ„h_{*}. The situation is completely different from the Ising model on regular non-amenable trees where there is no possibility of phase transition in the critical case for models with decaying fields, see [6].

We conjecture, as indicated in the Introduction, that there is phase uniqueness at low temperature when Î³<1âˆ’Î±ğ›¾1ğ›¼\gamma<1-\alpha, but we donâ€™t have a rigorous proof so far.

In the short-range Ising model in higher dimensions, uniqueness has been proven. In [4] the uniqueness for low temperatures was proven, adapting an argument from [9], afterwards the phase uniqueness for all temperatures was obtained combining this with a result from [15] using random cluster representations for models with fields. A direct argument proving the phase uniqueness for all Î²>0ğ›½0\beta>0 for Ising models with external fields decaying slowly is still unknown. We remark, by the way, that Potts models in a homogeneous field provide an example where there is both low-temperature uniqueness and high-temperature uniqueness, with a phase transition at some intermediate temperature, thus we will need to make use of some specific Ising properties.
